issues.title: Definition of slot/sub-slot
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
My thoughts and Sergio's comments labeled with [SB]

The issue is finding terminology that will be agreeable to network equipment vendors, data center people, and computer hardware people.  The idea is simple, but can be mapped onto different terminology.

For example.

A rack is a metal frame that may or may not contain electrical components that holds a chassis.

A standard rack holding something like a Cisco 8804 chassis looks like this.

![download](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f52983c7-d6dd-4e5a-8da5-716a02daa1aa)


The big holes you see in the picture above are slots.  There are slots on the back as well.  A slot can accept various modules, trays, or cards.  Some modules and/or cards can have daughter cards can be connected to the module or card.

 

Looking at the Network Inventory YANG terminology.

The rack, chassis and slots above are (as TMF puts them) holders. 

[SB>] YES the TMF separation between “holders” and “equipment” groups  is also in our document

An example of a sub-chassis could be a tray that holds other components (like fans).  In the Network Inventory YANG the term Board is (I think) a module or a card. 

[SB>] In our model a board is defined as” ianahw:module” , there is no distinction unfortunately from module to card/board.

Usually, modules are things like fans or power, so if we are modeling that we will need to differentiate a module from a card (so calling both of those board is probably wrong). 

[SB>]  Fan is considered as a specific card, it has a definition specific, not as ianahw:module .

There is a differentiation between cards as well (at least in Cisco-land).  There are “line cards” and “fabric cards”.  A line card has ports on it and in the case of optical pluggables a line card may have slots to accept pluggables. I don’t know if that is what is intended by the “sub-slot” terminology, but it could work since a pluggable would be considered a module that fits into a cards' sub-slot.  At least that is one interpretation. 

[SB>] In this case we would have a definition for sub-slot that should be “a slot of a line-card hosting an optical pluggable”

A “fabric card” is a card that “line cards” and sometimes modules plug into.  But here the "sub-slot" terminology doesn't really work very well, because the "sub-slot" on the "fabric card" is not inline with the slot the "fabric card" is in.  

What needs to be made clear is whether or not a “sub-slot” is simply a holder or if a “sub-slot” can be used for something like an optical pluggable.

[SB>] It can be used as a holder for an optical pluggable in my view.

I think a couple of examples to see what the instance data would look would help.

Looking at M.3100.  I would say recursive not circular.

 

A rack is made up of bays

A chassis is held in some number of bays of a rack depending on the size of the chassis.

A chassis has slots (or physical places to put things)

A chassis slot holds a "circuit pack" (which can be a line card, fabric card, computer, power, fans etc.)

A line card can also accept pluggables

 

I think leveraging M.3100 and mapping the terminology is a good exercise.  Things will get more interesting when the data center people show up and want to start talking about blades.

_Originally posted by @samans in https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/pull/75#discussion_r1909574652_

- [ ] @All: review the current proposal on the mailing list for further discussion in the call next week

The discussion on the list has pointed out that there are multiple interpretations of what a sub-shelf is: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/inventory-yang/LT9AMNqPEuu4EUMgE57lw33qXtE/

One possible definition for sub-shelf is to represent a shelf, within a multi-shelf NE, which has a hierarchical association with another shelf.

Another possible definition for sub-shelf is to represent the logical partitioning of the slots within a single shelf.

Nigel: the first interpretation is more associated with the functionality of the shelf rather than with the physical/inventory representation

Jeff: in the IP world we have the concept of satellite shelves

Nigel: Satellite is better term, than sub-shelf, to reference a shelf which has a hierarchical relationship with a main shelf

Agreed to use the term 'card' instead of 'board' consistently within the document.

Card: A pluggable equipment with a particular structural format and dimensions which can be inserted into one or more slots (or sub-slots). A card can have spaces to take other cards (called sub-slots). Elsewhere, a card can be called board, module, circuit pack, etc.

Slot: A space in a chassis that can be equipped with one card, which may be chosen from a limited range of types of cards. A slot can be subdivided into smaller spaces (called sub-slots).

**To be further reviewed in the next call**

Jeff: it is useful to report the trunk ports (as well as the WSS add/drop ports and the link between them) also in case of integrated OTs even if in this case, there is no link to be reported in the network topology model. More feedbacks from other operators are welcome

- [ ] @ju7ien: trigger some discussion in the IVY WG mailing list

Note 1: with integrated OTs it is assumed an hardware configuration where the OT and the WSS cards are different  cards (usually on different shelves) which belong to the same NE and connected trough an external cable (and not through the backplane)

Note 2: as a consequence, there is a requirement to report within the passive inventory both intra-NE and inter-NE cables

Nigel: Of course, like all passive inventory, the representation of the cable is (often) a statement of expectation, as the cable cannot be detected. Even where there is some mechanism for basic detection, the detector may not be functioning..

Sergio: Related to what Jeff is indicating about access-port in TAPI and the relationship between logical and physical model by access-port, we can say that in IETF we are on the same path with inventory-topology draft in which we make a reference between TP (termination point) and a port in inventory, where we abstract TP, and we make reference between a node to NE in the inventory, NE where we abstract node in topology model. 

Nigel: Note that the TAPI solution allows reference from the TP equivalent to the physical environment via AccessPort which provides a fine grain reference to connectors and pins where relevant (the solution allows various degrees of detail including a reference to a whole connector where all pins are used etc.). Whilst the full flexibility may not be needed at this point, it is important to ensure that we design the solution to enable enhancement to the full flexibility.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
Looking at the thread, it seems that the conclusion was that there was a good alternative proposal to address the issue but the suggestion was to do that in another PR since https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/pull/193  was quite old: https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/pull/193#issuecomment-2169133156

The drawback of the approach in https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-topology are that:
- we need to copy the same changes in multiple repositories
- if we need to change, all these repositories need to be changed
- we will face difficulties when the template is update to keep the repositories aligned any time the template from Martin Thomson is updated

For example, recently, github actions v3 support has been discontinued and the template from Martin Thomson has been updated to use github actions v4. Updating all the repositories to use the updated version of the template from Martin Thomson was quite straightforward because no changes were done on the files defined there. I am afraid that if we make changes to the core files, that work would have been more painful.

My preference is therefore to have an updated template which will make these enhancements available to all the repositories.

Alternative, if possible, we can create a new template forking from Martin Thomson's template and adding pyang validation checks. Then we just need to synch this fork with any update of Martin Thomson's template and not all the github repositories.

issues.title: Rationale behind containers with a single list
issues.author: tokarenko

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
It is common practice to define a list with a singular name within a container with the corresponding plural name

See section 4.3.1 of [draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22)

The rationale is mainly described in section 4.14.1 of [draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22) and [RFC 8407](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8407):

> The NETCONF and RESTCONF protocols do not currently support the ability to delete all list (or leaf-list) entries at once. This deficiency is sometimes avoided by use of a parent container (i.e., deleting the container also removes all child entries).

The interface model has only one list (with one "surrounding container") but follows the same approach

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:

> 
> See section 4.3.1 of [draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22)

> The rationale is mainly described in section 4.14.1 of [draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-netmod-rfc8407bis-22) and [RFC 8407](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8407):
> 
> > The NETCONF and RESTCONF protocols do not currently support the ability to delete all list (or leaf-list) entries at once. This deficiency is sometimes avoided by use of a parent container (i.e., deleting the container also removes all child entries).
> 
> The interface model has only one list (with one "surrounding container") but follows the same approach

@tokarenko : are you ok with the explanation above?

issues.title: Definition of shelf/sub-shelf
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
The discussion on issue #79 has pointed out that there are two possible interpretations for the definition of sub-shelf:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/inventory-yang/LT9AMNqPEuu4EUMgE57lw33qXtE/

> 
> One possible definition for sub-shelf is to represent a shelf, within a multi-shelf NE, which has a hierarchical association with another shelf.
> 
> Another possible definition for sub-shelf is to represent the logical partitioning of the slots within a single shelf.
> 
> Nigel: the first interpretation is more associated with the functionality of the shelf rather than with the physical/inventory representation
> 
> Jeff: in the IP world we have the concept of satellite shelves
> 
> Nigel: Satellite is better term, than sub-shelf, to reference a shelf which has a hierarchical relationship with a main shelf
> 

See: https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues/79#issuecomment-2701467344

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: See also slides presented at IETF 122: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-122-ivy-02-base-network-inventory-yang/

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-04-09 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-04-09)**

> * [ ] [@ALL](https://github.com/ALL): check the current implementations (if known)

> * [ ] [@nigel-r-davis](https://github.com/nigel-r-davis) check the existing definitions in ONF and TMF

Based on the discussion in previous calls and on the IVY WG mailing list discussion after the meeting, it seems that the modelling of multi-chassis NEs used in IP networks is quite clear.

The pending issue is about the modelling of multi-chassis NEs used in Optical networks.

- [x] @aguoietf @YuChaode @italobusi @nigel-r-davis @sergiobelotti check impact on existing optical NE implementations if the same approach discussed for multi-chassis NEs in IP networks is adopted

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> * [x]  [@aguoietf](https://github.com/aguoietf) [@YuChaode](https://github.com/YuChaode) [@italobusi](https://github.com/italobusi) [@nigel-r-davis](https://github.com/nigel-r-davis) [@sergiobelotti](https://github.com/sergiobelotti) check impact on existing optical NE implementations if the same approach discussed for multi-chassis NEs in IP networks is adopted

**Outcome of the joint discussion**

The term sub-shelf seems more applicable to the scenario in slide 13 of the IETF 122 since in this case it represents a part of the entire shelf.

Instead, in slide 14, there are different shelves with different hierarchical role (e.g., main shelf and subtended shelves).

Considering the concerns raised during the IETF 122 meeting on the scenario in slide 13 and that modelling this scenario does not seem a blocking issue for the WG LC of the base inventory model, we would suggest to create a new issue to address this scenario and mark it as an issue candidate for future revision or augmentation.

Instead, the scenario in slide 14 of the IETF 122 presentation can be modelled as a flat list of chassis (numbered as 1, 2, 3, …) as already discussed for the stacked chassis in IP NEs. The cables between them can be reported in the passive inventory model.

In the optical NEs, the different chassis have different role in the hierarchy where the main shelf is the chassis/shelf providing access to the management system. We can check with the IVY WG mailing list whether this information is relevant for the base inventory model.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-04-16 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-04-16)**

Reviewed https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues/101#issuecomment-2809110378

It has been noted that in the optical networks, the main chassis is usually configured by the operator while, from previous discussion, it seems that in the Ethernet switched networks the main chassis is usually automatically selected by some process within the NE. However, this different is not inherently technology-specific but just common implementation options and the models should support both regardless of the technology domain.

Note that this difference will be modelled in the first version of the base inventory model since everything is RO (the configuration of the main shelf can only be performed at device level and at the network level). However, this difference may become relevant in a future RFC updating the first version of the base inventory model.

The questions for discussion are:
- is there a need to report, within the network inventory, which the role of each chassis (main or subtended)
- if yes, how to represent this information: as a flag indicating the main chassis or as a role enumeration (main, subtended) indicating the role

issues.title: Splitting "common-entity-attributes" grouping into two groupings
issues.author: sergiobelotti
issues.body:
The grouping "common-entity-attributes" is used also in other inventory modules like Network inventory Location , ietf-ni-location module. Some of these common attributes are in fact not useful for location since more specific for NE/component , like hardware-rev, software-rev, and software-patch-rev.
For this reason it is needed to separate the grouping "common-entity-attributes" in two groupings one with minimal common entities (e.g. name, id, description etc..)   and the other with more specific NE/component attributes.

issues.title: Move component data into grouping for future reuse
issues.author: nigel-r-davis

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-05-21 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-05-21)**

Nigel has clarified that his proposal is to move the component attributes into a grouping which is used only once in the base inventory model but which can be re-used in other modules, if needed.

The proposed changes would have no impact on the base model YANG data tree and implementation.

YANG doctors usually comment when groupings used only once are defined: a note should be added to the grouping description indicating that component grouping has been defined as a common grouping to be re-used in other YANG modules.

comments.author: nigel-r-davis
comments.body:
We may want to explore my comment on component-assembly as it appears now that perhaps that is what an FRU is as opposed to a raw component. The assembly would allow the collection of non-FRU components to be collected together under the assembly and then to not have to have independent life. It would also allow software/firmware to be collected. 

This would be a further minor but powerful enhancement to the model.

If we think that this is worth while I could raise a separate issue.

issues.title: Slot should not be a component
issues.author: nigel-r-davis
issues.body:
Slot is not a component. It has no independent life (it is not separable from the equipment (chassis etc.)), It does not have a serial number and must have the same manufacturer as the thing it is a slot in. It does not have software or firmware and does not have any substance (as I have explained on several occasions before). I have not come across a model that treats slot as an equal to a board before. In TM Forum, we did originally mix up holder and equipment where a holder was a type of equipment, but we subsequently corrected that (as per ITU-T G.7711).

I propose the addition of an optional slot list to the component structure with the few properties that a slot actually has. I propose that this is the only approach to representation of slots and the slot as a component is not allowed in the standard usage.

This then means that a component is in a slot (or slots) of a component and hence references the slot leaf  (leaves) of the component. This can be a direct reference or an implicit list relationship. (better to cover the multi-slot occupancy challenge).

Looking at component, the lines marked <<<<<<< below is not relevant for a slot (i.e., most of them!).

           +--rw components
              +--rw component* [component-id]
                 +--rw component-id                        string
                 +--ro class                               union
                 +--ro uuid?                               yang:uuid <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--rw name?                               string
                 +--rw description?                        string
                 +--rw alias?                              string
                 +--ro hardware-rev?                       string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro software-rev?                       string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro software-patch-rev*                 string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro mfg-name?                           string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro mfg-date?                                  <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 |       yang:date-and-time
                 +--ro serial-number?                      string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro product-name?                       string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro firmware-rev?                       string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro part-number?                        string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro asset-id?                           string <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro child-component-ref
                 +--ro parent-rel-pos?                     int32
                 +--ro parent?
                 |       -> ../../component/component-id
                 +--ro is-fru?                             boolean <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro uri*                                inet:uri <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro chassis-specific-info <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro slot-specific-info
                 +--ro board-specific-info <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro port-specific-info <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--ro transceiver-module-specific-info <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                    +--ro breakout-channels!
                       +--ro breakout-channel* [channel-id]
                          +--ro channel-id    uint8

Taking the relevant attributes some are then no longer relevant if this is to be converted to a dedicated slot structure.

           +--rw components
              +--rw component* [component-id]
                 +--rw component-id                        string
                 +--ro class                               union <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 +--rw name?                               string
                 +--rw description?                        string
                 +--rw alias?                              string
                 +--ro child-component-ref
                 +--ro parent-rel-pos?                     int32
                 +--ro parent?                            <<<<<<<<<<<<<
                 |       -> ../../component/component-id
                 +--ro slot-specific-info

The slot structure then becomes… (some properties still look rather an overkill for slot)…

           +--rw slots?
              +--rw slot* [component-id]
                 +--rw slot-id                        string
                 +--rw name?                               string
                 +--rw description?                        string 
                 +--rw alias?                              string
                 +--ro child-component-ref
                 +--ro parent-rel-pos?                     int32
                 +--ro slot-specific-info

The above structure then becomes an optional part of the component. Where a component has slots, the structure appears.

To cover alternative slot usage we can have several slot maps and some equivalence, much like alternative channelization of a signal.

Note that LF TAPI equipment model covers actual and expected. This allows for preplanning. In a planning application the inventory has a time dimension and requires multiple things in a slot over time. We will need to add that later.

comments.author: nigel-r-davis
italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-06-04 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-06-04)**

Current model (updated with the list of parent components as proposed in https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues/3#issuecomment-2810488627):

```
- chassis-A
  - class: chassis
- slot-A1
  - class: container
  - parent: chassis-A
  - parent-position: 1 
- slot-A2
  - class: container
  - parent: chassis-A
  - parent-position: 2
- slot-A3
  - class: container
  - parent: chassis-A
  - parent-position: 3 
- slot-A4
  - class: container
  - parent: chassis-A
  - parent-position: 4 
- slot-A5
  - class: container
  - parent: chassis-A
  - parent-position: 5
- card-X
  - class: module
  - parent: slot-A1
- card-Y
  - class: module
  - parents: [
    slot-A3,
    slot-A4
  ]
```
Alternative model:

```
- chassis-A
  - class: chassis
  - occupied-slots: [
    1,
    2,
    3,
    4,
    5
  ]
- card-X
  - class: module
  - parent: chassis-A
  - occupied-slots: [
    1
  ]
- card-Y
  - class: module
  - parent: chassis-A
  - occupied-slots: [
    3,
    4
  ]
```

Note: with the alternative model, the container component class is no longer needed

It seems preferable to define the role in the spec and power management models rather than in the base inventory model reporting what is actually installed in the network. For example, the role blocked may not be sufficient to describe the cases where the blocking condition of a slot depend on power management (e.g., some cards which requires high power can be blocked while other cards which consume less power can be allowed).

Advantages of the proposed alternative model:

- closer to the reality of the physical thing where the slots are part of the component and have no separated lifecycle (TMF holder concept)
- significantly reduce the number of component instances in the component list
- removes confusion about properties defined for the components but not applicable to the slots/containers

issues.title: The Network Element
issues.author: nigel-r-davis
issues.body:
The NE is not a piece of hardware. The hardware is represented by a component. The NE is some kind of grouping/assembly statement for management-control or commercial purposes:
- It may be considered as an asset, although this is challenging.
- It may be in some form of inventory, but only as an assembly.
- It does not have a hardware rev, although it could have an assembly revision.
- It does not hold or run software directly, but may summarise the allowed/installed software on its various parts. 
- There will certainly be more than one instance of software in some cases and potentially multiple revs of each.
- It is assembled and this could be considered as a manufacture, but the date may be difficult to define (un-like for an atomic FRU).
- It does not have a proper serial number like a piece of hardware, although it may have an equivalent. (this may be on a label attached to one of the pieces of hardware it is assembled from).


           +--ro hardware-rev?         string
           +--ro software-rev?         string
           +--ro software-patch-rev*   string
           +--ro mfg-name?             string
           +--ro mfg-date?             yang:date-and-time
           +--ro serial-number?        string
           +--ro product-name?         string

For an NE that has a single piece of hardware (e.g., a pizza box), this would be an NE with one component representing the actual hardware.
Note that once we deal with expected/actual in the device, then the controller view of an NE that is a pizza box where there is an expectation and the actual hardware reported is inconsistent, the NE could have two "components", one expected and one actual, etc.

The base model cannot cover complex scenarios where for example multiple SW modules are associated with a single NE or single hardware component. The SW inventory model has been designed to cover these complex scenarios

Two concerns with removing the SW information from the base inventory model:
- making mandatory to implement the SW inventory model also in simple scenarios where there is only one OS for the NE and one SW module running on the component
- the SW inventory model is re-using the component list defined in the base inventory model to model SW modules

Chassis is currently defined by reference to iana-hardware

The definition of the shelf proposed on the IVY mailing list was:

```
Shelf: An equipment with a particular structural format.
       A shelf includes slots.
       A shelf is field replaceable.
```

We can try to derive the following definition for chassis:

```
Chassis: A field replaceable equipment with a particular structural format.

         Elsewhere, a chassis can be called shelf, sub-rack, etc.
```

issues.title: Definition of port and potential need to introduce the "connector"
issues.author: nigel-r-davis
issues.body:
As we know, port is a somewhat ambiguous term. The definition needs further refinement.

In addition, the "physical port" is potentially actually a "connector" which may help clarify the port definition, but leads to the need to define connector.

In TAPI, AccessPort and Connector are defined. AccessPort is a logical abstraction of pins in a connector that support a single signal flow. I will provide definitions from TAPI.

I will aim to provide an improved definition in ivy for port and a definition for connector.

The relevant current definition (where port is mentioned) are:

Port: : A component where networking traffic can be received and/or transmitted, e.g., by attaching networking cables. : In case of pluggable ports, the port may be empty when no transceiver module is plugged in.

Physical interface: : An interface associated to a physical port. A physical interface is always in the lowest layer of the interface stack.

Logical interface: : An interface which is not associated to a physical port.

Breakout Port: : A port is usually associated with a single physical interface. A breakout port is a port which is broken down and associated into multiple physical interfaces. Those physical interfaces can have the same or different speeds and the same or different number of breakout channels.

Trunk Port: : A trunk port is a port which is associated with one and only physical interface.

Port Breakout: : The configuration of a breakout port.

Summary of the mailing list discussion:
- ok to move the modelling of the breakout ports to the topology model
- concern with the use of term "logical", what about "functional"?
- It is not clear whether the configuration of the host interface needs to be exposed in a network model or could be done within the host OS. What is needed is a way to reference components across models: the NPU interfaces could be represented by a TP in the 8944 L2 topology model and as long as the model representing breakouts can associate the NPU interface to the transceiver channel that should be fine.

Agreed to use the term "functional" instead of "logical"

This issue related with the configuration of the host interface needs further clarification in the context of the new topology model for the breakout configurations and it is outside the current scope of the base inventory model.

issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
**[2025-07-30 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-07-30)**

Actions based on IETF 123 IVY WG feedbacks:

- [ ] define a list of (software-name, software-rev) for the components

Additional considerations:
1. the list of active software should also contain the software patches for each software-name instance
2. since this list reports only the active SW modules, the software-name can be used as a key for this list
3. the firmware revision can be removed and the software-rev list can be used also to report running firmware modules
4. the approach can also be extened to the NE for consistency

It was also noted that the term firmware is sometimes used to refer to a read-only code (e.g., BIOS) which cannot be upgraded and sometimes used to refer to the programmable code of an FPGA which can be upgraded. By defining only the software-rev list can cover any type of programming data (including firmware) would resolve this ambiguity in the context of the base inventory model. They type of code can be distinguished from the name attribute.

OLD

     +--rw network-elements
        +--rw network-element* [ne-id]
           +--rw ne-id                 string
           +-- ...
           +--ro software-rev?         string
           +--ro software-patch-rev*   string
           +-- ...
           +--ro components
              +--rw component* [component-id]
                 +--rw component-id           string
                 +--ro class                  union
                 +-- ...
                 +--ro hardware-rev?          string
                 +--ro software-rev?          string
                 +--ro software-patch-rev*    string
                 +-- ...
                 +--ro firmware-rev?          string
                 +-- ...

NEW

     +--rw network-elements
        +--rw network-element* [ne-id]
           +--rw ne-id                 string
           +-- ...
           +--ro software-rev [name]
           |  +--ro name          string
           |  +--ro revision?     string
           |  +--ro patch-rev*    string
           +-- ...
           +--ro components
              +--rw component* [component-id]
                 +--rw component-id           string
                 +--ro class                  union
                 +-- ...
                 +--ro hardware-rev?          string
                 +--ro software-rev [name]
                 |  +--ro name          string
                 |  +--ro revision?     string
                 |  +--ro patch-rev*    string
                 +-- ...
                 +-- ...

**[2025-09-03 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-09-03)**

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> * [x]  [@italobusi](https://github.com/italobusi) check with IVY WG the additional thoughts from the call on July 30 ([Multiple software revisions #128 (comment)](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues/128#issue-3277584928))

See: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ivy/BnUmYN6UOILyiDlEmxeo7RvW6ns/

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-09-17 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-09-17)**

> > * [x]   [@italobusi](https://github.com/italobusi) check with IVY WG the additional thoughts from the call on July 30 ([Multiple software revisions #128 (comment)](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues/128#issue-3277584928))
> 
> See: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ivy/BnUmYN6UOILyiDlEmxeo7RvW6ns/

Summary of the mailing list discussion:
- sometimes software patch version/rev is part of the software name (or rev) and is not a separate field. For example, if the software version is 8.2.1, the patched version is 8.2.1.P1. Can the description of the software-rev field be relaxed to say that it denotes either the software-rev or a patched version of the image (and remove the software-patch-rev field)
- a possible option is to move the software-patch-rev under a presence container to indicate whether the software patches are explicitly reported or implicitly reported as part of the software name/rev

It has been noted that the software revision and patches are optional and therefore a vendor can decide to report the software patch version as part of the software name or revision. There is no need for a presence container to avoid ambiguity since this is a vendor choice.

It is therefore preferred not to change the model and just improve the descriptions to allow these implementation choices.

- [x] @italobusi update the description of the software revision and patches to allow these implementation options

It has also been noted that the SW inventory model can extend the base inventory model to report additional information for the SW patches (e.g., the time the patch has been installed).

It has been agreed to change the list of software patches from leaf-list to a list which can be used as an augmentation target by the SW inventory model:

OLD

```
           |  +--ro patch-rev*   string
```
NEW

```
           |  +--ro patch* [revision]
           |     +--ro revision?    string
```

- [x] @italobusi discuss these comments and proposal with the IVY WG mailing list
- [x] @italobusi update the  software patches as a list instead of as a leaf-list

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body:
I think the two-level software-and-patch list is too heavy.  
How about we use one flat software-version list with an optional “type” (version/release/patch); it keeps the base model small and covers any combination.  
If a vendor needs a deeper hierarchy, the SW inventory extension can always add parent/child relationships.

comments.author: italobusi
sergiobelotti
comments.body:
> I think the two-level software-and-patch list is too heavy. How about we use one flat software-version list with an optional “type” (version/release/patch); it keeps the base model small and covers any combination. If a vendor needs a deeper hierarchy, the SW inventory extension can always add parent/child relationships.

@lana-wu Could you elaborate a bit what do you mean with "flat software-version list " not clear to me . This would permit also to help the comment below with the three scenarios described by Italo , but not sure his interpretation of your "flal list" is correct.

comments.author: italobusi
lana-wu
comments.body:
I agree that the flat SW revision list doesn’t show the clear relationship between patches and its software revision.  
However, a software module normally has only one active revision, so the patches should apply only to that active revision anyway.

In summary, I have no objection to the current hierarchical YANG definition.  I can see that the present definition is more flexible and leaves room for us to capture the link between (1) the currently-active revision and (2) historical revisions plus their patch states.

issues.title: Definitions from IANA-HW
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
The following terms are defined by reference to the identities defined in the "iana-hardware" module:
- backplane
- battery
- container
- cpu
- chassis
- fan
- module
- port
- power supply
- sensor
- stack
- storage device

These definitions are used to generalize the definition of hardware component.

However there is this Editors' Note to be resolved:

> Editors' Note: The chassis and port definition below needs to be moved to iana-hardware update

It is worth noting that in addition to chassis and port, the I-D is defining also the concept of container and the concept of card (modelled as a module)

Could we provide a clean definition for the following terms (or equivalent terms as we have done for card versus module):
- backplane
- battery
- cpu
- fan
- power supply
- sensor
- storage device


Looking at the current text and example, maybe we can leave the concept of 'stack' outside the scope of the first RFC

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-09-03 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-09-03)**

There are two options:

1. reduce the list of terms defined by reference to IANA-HW (removing the terms which have been already defined in this I-D, such as port, chassis, ...)

1. provide a definition for each of the component type defined in IANA-HW within this document and do not reference IANA-HW for defining these terms

To be further discussed in the next calls

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-09-17 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-09-17)**

Option 1 has been agreed.

This does not preclude anybody to provide a definition for the terms which are currently defined only by reference to IANA-HW. If the definition is agreed, it could be added to the document replacing the definition by reference to IANA-HW.

Alternatively, it is also possible to start a new work item to update IANA-HW.

In this way, there is no need to update the current definitions in IANA-HW before the WG LC of the base inventory model.

issues.title: RO or RW attributes
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
**[2025-09-17 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-09-17)**

It is not clear why some attributes are marked as RW and not RO, considering the current scope:

> The YANG data model defined in the document is intended to only report actual inventory data which includes both applied configuration data and state data of the network elements and components actually installed within the network.

The only RW attributes are the list keys, name, description and alias.

It has been agreed that these attributes can be configured on the device but not in the network inventory. These attributes should be re-defined as RO to report the applied configuration on the device.

- [x] @italobusi raise this comment to the IVY WG 
- [ ] @italobusi update the YANG data model accordingly

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> **[2025-09-17 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-09-17)**
> 
> * [x]  [@italobusi](https://github.com/italobusi) raise this comment to the IVY WG

See: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ivy/iI0s9QDvVrDNmyMXlbrKo_6qUOM/

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-10-01 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-10-01)**

Slides describing the current scope/workflows and potential issues on modifying the scope/workflow: [inventory-config-workflow-00.pptx](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22644977/inventory-config-workflow-00.pptx)

It has been clarified that this model is implemented in the network controller and not in the device

The purpose of this model is to report the data that the network controller  knows and therefore it is only providing a read-only perspective.

Better not to mention that the model include both applied configuration and state data to avoid configuration

The information in the model is populated by controller by reading it from the devices using the device model supported by the devices. This model does not constraint the device models used on the device: RFC8348 is an option but other options (e.g., vendor specific models) are also allowed.

In case some information is not provided by the device, the network controller SHALL omit this information unless this information is known by other sources of information (e.g., through local configuration within the network controller).

The ne-id should be unique within the network (since it is the key of the  network-element list). The device cannot guaranteed that its identifier is unique within the network and therefore the ne-id should be administered by the network controller.

The ne-id should be assigned such that the same network element will always be identified through the same identifier, even if the network elements get disconnected from the network controller. Mechanisms to ensure this (e.g., checking the mfg-name, product-name, management IP address, physical location) are implementation specific and outside the scope of standardization.

- [ ] @italobusi Update the text in the I-D

comments.body:
As reported in the description of component-specific-info grouping what is indicated in the structure is specific attributes related to specific type of component e.g. chassis, container etc. 
I would change the text as "Attributes related to specific class of component can be found in the component-specific-info structure".
Why part-number is still present in the sub-tree of NE?

Thank you Sergio! I changed this sentence to be "Different types of components can be distinguished by the class of component. The component "class" is defined as a union between the hardware class identity, defined in "iana-hardware", and the "non-hardware" identity, defined in this document. Attributes related to specific class of component can be found in the component-specific-info structure." In the previous discussion, Italo suggested to remove class attribute and different types of components can be identified by the component-specific structure. I raised a concern that it is hard to do a filtering if there is not a class attribute. So I prefer to keeping class attribute still in this draft at first, and whetherto keep it or not still needs more discussions.
Thanks Sergio! I removed this part-number from tree structure today. But there is still some debate on removing part-number/repacing it with assembly-id/module-name in Issue#33.
Hi Chaode, yes I know about assembly-id , my suggestion was only on the fact that in YANG modeule part-numer does not appear anymore, but is still there in the tree.  Thanks

reviews.author: italobusi
reviews.body:
Few comments to be addressed before merging the PR:
1. Please update the YANG revision date every time the YANG module is updated;
2. See also some detailed review comments within the files changed

Additional comments that may be addressed after the PR is merged (if not addressed, we can track them as new open issues):
1. There is no need for empty grouping for the component-specific attributes. An empty container defined as an augmentation target should be enough for the base network inventory model
2. It is preferable to avoid defining grouping when used once unless this would help the readability of the code

comments.body:
The `component-class` is at the same level as `component-id`:

```suggestion
+--rw components
   +--rw component* [component-id]
      +--rw component-id            string
      .......................................
      +--rw (component-class)?
         +--:(chassis)
         |  +--rw chassis-specific-info
         +--:(container)
         |  +--rw slot-specific-info
         +--:(module)
         |  +--rw board-specific-info
         +--:(port)
         |  +--rw port-specific-info
         +--:(software)
            +--rw software-specific-info
```
In order to have an appendix number, please move this text before the `{: numbered="false"}` code
I think you need to import iana-hardware: it is used by the class data node below

Unless we agree that this model can only be used as RO, it is possible that some component-specific attribute might be RW. It is suggested not to preclude this option:

reviews.author: philbedard
reviews.body: Just the clarification on the class section otherwise the rest looked good.

comments.body: thank you Sergio, now it is removed.
Thank you Italo, now it is moved to the same level with component-id.
Fixed.
Thank you, it is added back.
Now this structure is configable. But i have a concern that the change from RW to RO will be a NBC.
Sorry Phil, this structure is actually designed for additional attributes specific to a single type of component.  Just like what we said in the section of 2.4.2.

Maybe you are talking about the opposite, I mean to move data nodes for RO to RW, this is what Italo is asking for.
I do not see any issue here taking into account what RFC7950 is indicating in section 3 as Italo pointed out in other context (Optical impairment weekly call)

The `{: numbered="false"}` code should be kept for the Acknowledgments section which is not numbered as an appendix

I have also noted that the current md file defines an Appendix with title Appendix which is not needed (the '--- back' indicates that the following paragraphs are appendices)

Proposed changes:

OLD

```
--- back

# Appendix

## Comparison With Openconfig-platform Data Model

<...>

## Efficiency Issue

<...>

# Acknowledgments
```

NEW 

```
--- back

# Comparison With Openconfig-platform Data Model

<...>

# Efficiency Issue

<...>

{: numbered="false"}

# Acknowledgments

```

Please note that the NBC change requirement applies only to YANG modules published as IETF RFCs. NBC changes are allowed between different versions of I-Ds.

The issues related to the level of configuration is required for the inventory model are still open: https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Aconfig
Thanks Italo, now it is fixed.

I guess you meant [RFC 8348](https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&ved=2ahUKEwi4w_z21aSKAxU_UaQEHQuRC98QFnoECBYQAQ&url=https%3A%2F%2Fdatatracker.ietf.org%2Fdoc%2Fhtml%2Frfc8348&usg=AOvVaw37XEzeeG-tUB3JYKmiSmSS&opi=89978449)

```suggestion
: The generalization of the hardware components defined in {{IANA_YANG}} (e.g., backplane, battery, container, cpu, chassis, fan, module, port, power supply, sensor, stack, and storage device components).
```

We can't formally add directly those to the IANA module. These should be added to IANA-ENTITY-MIB:

```
>    The "iana-hardware" YANG module is intended to reflect the
>    "IANA-ENTITY-MIB" MIB module so that if a new enumeration is added to
>    the "IANAPhysicalClass" textual convention, the same class is added
>    as an identity derived from "ianahw:hardware-class".
```

My understanding is that these terms are defined in the description statements of the component classes identities within [IANA_YANG]

```suggestion
The following terms are defined in the description statements of the corresponding YANG identities, defined in {{IANA_YANG}}, and are not redefined here:
```
See: https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/pull/75/files#r1886557028

My thoughts and Sergio's comments labeled with [SB]

The issue is finding terminology that will be agreeable to network equipment vendors, data center people, and computer hardware people.  The idea is simple, but can be mapped onto different terminology.

For example.

A rack is a metal frame that may or may not contain electrical components that holds a chassis.

A standard rack holding something like a Cisco 8804 chassis looks like this.

![download](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f52983c7-d6dd-4e5a-8da5-716a02daa1aa)


The big holes you see in the picture above are slots.  There are slots on the back as well.  A slot can accept various modules, trays, or cards.  Some modules and/or cards can have daughter cards can be connected to the module or card.

 

Looking at the Network Inventory YANG terminology.

The rack, chassis and slots above are (as TMF puts them) holders. 

[SB>] YES the TMF separation between “holders” and “equipment” groups  is also in our document

An example of a sub-chassis could be a tray that holds other components (like fans).  In the Network Inventory YANG the term Board is (I think) a module or a card. 

[SB>] In our model a board is defined as” ianahw:module” , there is no distinction unfortunately from module to card/board.

Usually, modules are things like fans or power, so if we are modeling that we will need to differentiate a module from a card (so calling both of those board is probably wrong). 

[SB>]  Fan is considered as a specific card, it has a definition specific, not as ianahw:module .

There is a differentiation between cards as well (at least in Cisco-land).  There are “line cards” and “fabric cards”.  A line card has ports on it and in the case of optical pluggables a line card may have slots to accept pluggables. I don’t know if that is what is intended by the “sub-slot” terminology, but it could work since a pluggable would be considered a module that fits into a cards' sub-slot.  At least that is one interpretation. 

[SB>] In this case we would have a definition for sub-slot that should be “a slot of a line-card hosting an optical pluggable”

A “fabric card” is a card that “line cards” and sometimes modules plug into.  But here the "sub-slot" terminology doesn't really work very well, because the "sub-slot" on the "fabric card" is not inline with the slot the "fabric card" is in.  

What needs to be made clear is whether or not a “sub-slot” is simply a holder or if a “sub-slot” can be used for something like an optical pluggable.

[SB>] It can be used as a holder for an optical pluggable in my view.

I think a couple of examples to see what the instance data would look would help.

Looking at M.3100.  I would say recursive not circular.

 

A rack is made up of bays

A chassis is held in some number of bays of a rack depending on the size of the chassis.

A chassis has slots (or physical places to put things)

A chassis slot holds a "circuit pack" (which can be a line card, fabric card, computer, power, fans etc.)

A line card can also accept pluggables

 

I think leveraging M.3100 and mapping the terminology is a good exercise.  Things will get more interesting when the data center people show up and want to start talking about blades.

Now used by the text added in https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/pull/75/commits/d493a0e77dd8f728bd0e69f3e5ed40c4ea11aa7a to clarify that the scope is only to report actual inventory data and not to configure planned/intended inventory data, as per mailing list discussion:

**[2024-12-18 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2024-12-18)**

Definitions of transceiver, transceiver module and port:

Transceiver: A transceiver represents a transmitter/receiver (Tx/Rx) pair which is transmitting and receiving a signal from the media.
This definition generalizes the transceiver definition in [I-D.ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang] to model also non optical transceivers (e.g., electrical transceivers).

Transceiver Module: A module which contains one or more
transceivers (e.g., optical or electrical transceivers).
A transceivers-module component can only be contained by a
port component.

Note: The last sentence (i.e., "A transceivers module can only be contained within a port component.") needs to be validated after having reviewed the inventory examples for modelling integrated ROADM add/drop modules

Port: A component where networking traffic can be received and/or transmitted, e.g., by attaching transceiver modules and networking cables.

Note: This definition needs to be validated after having reviewed the inventory examples for modelling OTS ports on ROADM degrees

**[2025-02-05 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-02-05)**

c/atomic elements/atomic resource elements/

Need to continue the discussion about:
- relationship between breakout channels and line channels (and the need to define breakout channels)
- clarify that port breakout is different than channelizing an interface into multiple (logical) sub-interfaces (e.g., VLAN sub-interfaces)
- whether the multiple interfaces associated with a breakout port are physical or logical interfaces (and whether there is a need to disambiguate the definition of physical and logical interfaces)

Nigel: The term "physical" is used in our work to cover both the genuinely physical thing (i.e., a thing that can be measured with a ruler (has spatial dimensions) and sometimes by scales (has mass)) and some functional things that are closely associated with the physical thing. Whilst a pure definition of physical, with no functional aspects, would be preferable, the word is misused extensively across the industry and hence we have to align with that misuse.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**[2025-02-19 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-02-19)**

Interfaces are by definition logical concept. The physical interface term can be used to represent the interface in the lowest layer of the interface stack associated a physical port.

- [x] @italobusi add some note to the draft clarifying that channelizing an interface (e.g., an Ethernet interface) into multiple logical sub-interfaces (e.g., VLAN interfaces) is not port breakout and outside the scope of the inventory models.

It has been clarified that the intention for defining the concept of breakout channels is to make the model more flexible and independent from the technology (e.g., optical) and the specific implementations. In case of 400G-DR4 implementations, the breakout channels map 1:1 with the line channels: the intention is to describe this mapping in an appendix (text still to be developed).

In the 400G-DR4 examples, there are two host channels associated with a single line channel. However, it is not possible to associate two different interfaces with two different host channels if they are associated with the same line channel.

While the association between the physical interfaces, host channels and line channels is relevant for device configuration (and supported by OpenConfig), from network inventory perspective, only the associations between the physical interfaces (abstracted as physical LTPs) and the line channels is relevant. Therefore the line channels can be reported in the network inventory model as breakout channels.

The appendix with the examples of breakout configuration can be completed in the next update: issue #93  has been created to complete the example

Agreed to review the PR before the next call (February 26, 2025) with the objective to be able to merge it before IETF 122 cut-off deadline

**[2025-02-26 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-02-26)**

```suggestion
Reporting whether a port, which supports port breakout, is configured as a trunk or as a breakout port, is outside the scope of the base network inventory model. The model providing the mapping between the topology and the inventory models should provide sufficient information to identify how the port is configured and, in case of breakout configuration, which breakout channel is associated with which Link Termination Point (LTP), abstracting a device physical interface within the topology model.
```

**[2025-02-26 Base Network Inventory weekly call](https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/wiki/minutes-2025-02-26)**

Accepted the proposal in https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/pull/76/files#r1971415237

I have a doubt about a global replacement of network inventory with network-wide inventory

The terms 'network inventory model' and 'base network inventory model' are already of common use and I am not sure about the feedbacks from IVY WG if we replace then wit 'network-wide inventory model' and 'base network-wide inventory model'

 uses basic-common-entity-attributes;

reviews.author: italobusi
reviews.body:
Mainly editorial comments to align the terminology used in the draft and in the YANG model plus few suggested rephrasing

Note: if needed, the terminology used in the YANG model can also be updated with a better terminology. What is important is to be consistent.

comments.body:
We are defining SW information also for components:

```suggestion
This document defines a "software-rev" list for NEs and components, which provide
basic software attributes for network elements and components.
```

The text introduces the concept of "working software running" without defining it. For the YANG description, we have agreed to use the terminology "software modules configured to be active within the entity": see https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/pull/131#issuecomment-3306550085

Better to align the terminology in the draft and in the YANG:

```suggestion
The scope of the list is to provide information about the software modules configured to be active 
on the related entity (network element or component).

The model supports scenarios where multiple software modules can be configured to be active on the entity. For example, on a network element an Operating System and an Application software modules can be configured to be active; in the same way, on a component like a circuit pack a boot-loader, a firmware 
and one or more FPGA software modules can be configured to be active.

For each software module, configured to be active, the name and version information is provided.
```

I would say that this is out of scope of the base inventory model:

```suggestion
The management of inactive/standby software 
modules and of the software upgrade or downgrade life-cycle are outside the scope of the base inventory model and can be addressed in other models which augment the base inventory model such as the model under definition in {{?I-D.ietf-ivy-network-inventory-software}}. 
```
